abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Social Action
            Project for Sierra Leone were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            pilot rural public works program proved very useful in
            laying the foundation for International Development
            Association (IDA) to respond promptly to evolving country
            priorities and scale up safety nets support in the face of
            shocks. This underscored the importance of having scalable
            safety nets systems in place before the onset of shocks in
            order to respond effectively and in a well-targeted manner.
            In fragile states, requiring counterpart funding from
            Government can be counter-productive, especially when other
            forms of ensuring government ownership are possible.
            Government provision of counterpart funding became a problem
            soon after the project commenced, as noted in the 2005
            Country Portfolio Performance Review (CPPR). Government
            displayed other signs of ownership, and implementation will
            have proceeded more smoothly with 100 percent Bank
            financing. The implementation of a sustained and tailored
            capacity building program was important in fostering
            community participation with local government in all stages
            of the subproject cycle in a post conflict environment. The
            creation of Project Management Committees (PMCs) served as a
            catalyst in mobilizing communities to effectively
            participate and perform their oversight and monitoring
            functions. This in turn strengthened a sense of ownership
            and led to sustained support to operations and maintenance.
            The restoration of infrastructure and essential services, in
            addition to their own merits, also generated social benefits
            by promoting cohesiveness, rebuilding trust and fostering
            community engagement.
